*To the Tune of "Picking Mulberries"*
For Sister Wang, whose nature is vast in samādhi, prajñā, and emptiness—
The hollow valley transmits the spirit.
Formless, celestial truth,
Clapping the cosmos shut—her visage utterly pure.

Through the years, unimpeded, the perfect brightness appears,
Unchanging, ever-spring.
The ancestral intent made manifest,
Yin’s essence and yang’s essence—a body beyond the body.

**II**
The pearl of nature gleams, clear as the moon over the dhyāna heavens.
Light flows through the three realms,
Auspicious signs fill the four seas.
Qi and spirit meet, descending jade frost.

The divine sprout evenly steeped, golden flowers bloom,
Fragrance suffuses her being.
Musk sprays the bright hall,
Through kalpas, the ancestral wind and Dao’s transformation flourish.

**III**
Wisdom’s light pierces through the coarse heart’s dross,
Severing thought, forgetting emotion.
Form still, spirit clear—
She cradles forth the perfect emptiness, a single gleam of brightness.

Sweeping clouds, dispelling mist, her divine mechanism triumphs,
Roaming free in all directions.
True form defies naming—
She brandishes radiance, illuminating the eight reaches.

**IV**
The pivot of will moves through stillness and motion, diligent from dawn to dusk,
Delighting in hardship and obscurity.
Subtle signs interflow,
Bellows and keys breathe in harmony with the Great Void.

The craftsman forges the body of pure yang through subdued fire,
Dharma realms merge in emptiness.
The true work of creation—
The cosmos entire returns to her grasp.

*To the Tune of "Green-Headed Duck"*
The Dao’s wind pure,
Martial curtains intertwine in ceaseless weaving.
Gathering the three heavens, harmonizing the two lands,
Revolving the primal palace—true qi flows.

Transforming hardness and softness, dragon and mare roam,
Responding to the seventy-two seasonal nodes.
Jade runs, gold flies,
Smoke spouts, mist is drawn—
Water and fire swiftly meet in union.

The six yin disperse, the three yang gather in the cauldron,
The elixir’s essence blooms in splendor.
Fragrant winds attend, golden light suffuses her form,
A few strands of rosy dawn gleam.

Suddenly the foundation opens—
Nature manifests in every detail,
Penetrating the great thousandfold worlds in all directions.
A gentle breeze carries her, soaring and leaping,
Treading the clouds, her bearing majestic.

Neither form nor emptiness,
Neither increase nor decrease—
The ocean’s treasure, the wish-fulfilling gem, emits true crystal.
Within and without, radiance flows unimpeded,
Her divine powers welcome the six penetrations.

Her primordial visage—
Work accomplished, vast and boundless,
Beyond all naming.

**II**
Her body rare and subtle,
The mysterious female of the valley-spirit as foundation.
Qi coils back through three thousand six hundred turns,
Tracing the twin passes—wind and waves ripple.

Around the golden city, the mud ox drags the phoenix,
Across the jade path, the wooden horse consults the tortoise.
Seven returns to the true,
Nine restorations of life—
The sacred embryo forms, auspicious mist suffuses.

Reciting prajñā, she strays not from samādhi,
Attaining the shore, she realizes non-action.
Beyond the true realm—
Crimson light and white radiance,
Entering and exiting, ever attendant.

The grotto-heaven gleams, pure and serene,
Her yang soul races lightly, swiftly as the wind.
She wields the spirit’s brilliance, boundless and resplendent,
Her countenance through the ages shines in full glory.

The wind of purity, the life of emptiness,
A vast and sudden point—utterly unblemished.
Unleashing the sacred transformation, penetrating heaven and earth,
The pearl reveals its mani-jewel.

Thus and thus, soaring and still—
Everywhere, the jade pools.

*To the Tune of "Drizzling Rain"*
The myriad conditions—her heart rests.

Releasing the spirit, emotions flow harmonious—
Chronic ailments retreat to their hidden dens.
The Dao’s work in clarity and emptiness ascends,
The subtle spirit breathes, its movement unhurried.

The Seven Luminaries greet the true in a pristine chamber,
Cool radiance, bones like frost.
Above the nine heavens, before the twelve towers,
The five qi surge skyward, veiling the golden palace.

Raising high the sword of wisdom, immortal youths pay homage,
Advancing its frigid light—
The keen edge lifts sun and moon.
Gathering the resplendent essence,
Concentrating in the crucible, stirring the mysterious frost to bloom.

Something takes form—
The supreme marvel returns to the nebulous.
The vastness of the nature-sea, steeped in non-action,
Gracefully transcends the Three Voids.

**II**
Qian’s primal potency begins,
While Kun’s gentle yielding shapes all things,
Silently harmonizing with heaven’s essence.
The transformations of creation, pure and empty,
Move the three essentials, the five phases’ divine water.

Nine qi surge skyward, the six yin stilled—
Purple mists arise in secret.
Manifesting ascent and descent, ebb and return to the origin,
The jade cavern’s three flowers unfurl golden pistils.

The Jade Emperor’s treasury, the wind-harp’s beauty—
Escorting the blue maidens,
The Crimson Palace feasts the red child.
Conch cups brim, fragrant waves rise,
Unrestrained, the great draught pours forth true joy.

Beyond the mundane, towering—
The yang body revealed, freed from life and death.
Across vast ages, bones revolve in cycles,
Yet this life’s end is perfectly clear.

*Collected Writings on Meeting the True, Scroll Four Concludes*
*Collected Writings on Meeting the True, Scroll Five*

Master Chaoran Wang Jichang’s *Manjianghong*

That primal spark—
from the first, beyond birth and extinction.
Yet chasing shadows, it falls into yin and yang,
shaped into form, its face and features ever-changing.
In this turbid age of five defilements,
the eight sufferings press and sear—
born, then dead; dead, then born again,
when will this cycle of birth and death end?

I teach you awakening,
your will seizing the mystery of the Yellow and the Dark.
The seven luminaries thread the three wonders,
the pivot of the pearl and the jade wheel stirs, qi flowing.
Nine returns, seven reversals,
the elixir timed and tempered—
in the golden cavern, jade blossoms unfurl,
five qi soaring as crimson snow.

*Drunken Ecstasy*
Nourish the vast with fasting heart.
The true work of the five phases overturned—
a divine wind rises and falls through the three isles of teeth.
The merit aligns with the celestial circuit,
the True One embraced within.

Form sustains the formless Dao,
the passionless brews the treasure of passion.
Upholding the body’s health, the spirit endures forever.
Alone, the dhyāna heavens revealed,
the heart illumined by the moon’s bright radiance.

*The Golden Goblet*
Lock the monkey-mind,
thoughts sinking deep.
In profound obscurity, the subtle mechanism turns—
southern fire, northern abyss of metal.
Open the mercury crucible, tiger and dragon roar.
Nourish the nine qi, strip away the host of yin.
Pour the wine diligently, the wind-harp’s melody.
Send off the wooden lad with a great draught of drunkenness.
The six viscera flow, the five spirits feast.
Cross into the sage’s realm, shed the mortal garb.
The pure and tranquil body—
even ghosts and gods revere it.

*Second Stanza*
Preserve the celestial true,
nurture the primordial spirit.
Harmonize the two substances, brew the eastern sun’s wine.
Follow heaven’s reckoning, respond to the hour.
Withdraw and replenish with care, rise at *gengshen*.
Refine the mercury medicine, smelt the lead and silver.
Eight jades renewed, the snow-flesh even.
Crimson clouds blanket the earth, fragrant winds stir.
The guest from the west—
his intent pure and refined.
In the dream of *Huaxu*, dreaming through spring,
he returns beyond things, revealing his whole body.

*Third Stanza*

**Knock at the Mystic Pass, tread the clouded peaks.**
Flower-glow and stone-luster, pine-winds soft.
The zither dispels vexation, wine unfolds the face.
The heart’s truth soars free, the mind at ease.
All realms dissolve—I alone endure.
Nine suns return, six yins are pared away.
Gather the eight treasures, golden light brims full.
The body fuses and shines, rosy clouds deepen.
Form and reality merge, the Great Void unbroken.
Welcome the immortal guest, transcend the dusty world.

*Fourth Stanza*
Sever dust-bound passions, wisdom’s wind arises.
Heaven’s gate and earth’s pivot serve as levers.
The mystic mechanism turns, the Dipper’s hub revolves.
Toad marrow, sun-crow essence—
*ren*-palace gathers, jade crucible refines.
Lush blossoms bloom, the ten thousand spirits grow clear.
Three Terraces and Six Auxiliaries celebrate in the celestial palace.
Feast on jade nectar, ferment the true essence.
Return to the sea of awakening, merge into perfect completion.
Behold the sovereign self—majestic in form.

*Fifth Stanza*
Emerald mists clear, ripples pure.
Light drifts o’er the thatched hut, pine windows still.
At dusk, I don my robe, the zither across my lap.
Idle chanting, content in true feeling.
Poverty brings joy—greater than duke or minister.
Favor brings no pride, disgrace no alarm.
The numinous terrace nurtures, the balance shifts.
Zen moon serene, the nature-pearl bright.
Samādhi unravels, the six penetrations refined.
The supreme Dao—attained in perfect completion.

---

**Drunk in Penglai**
The primal form, one qi, thrones divide heaven and earth,
Uncarved simplicity reveals its auspice.
Through boundless kalpas, none escape—
ensnared by yin and yang’s weave.
Sudden awakening turns back, light harmonizes gold,
Wood clusters *kan* and *li*’s essence.
Miasma winds howl, clouds drift, rain descends—
the elixir’s foundation evenly steeped.
Nine gatherings, three epochs, six lines’ numbers fulfilled,
Odd and even multiply, the Valley Spirit leaves its vessel.
Piercing Kunlun’s summit, I seize the clear wind in play.
Reclining at ease, white clouds amass,
lost in blissful drunkenness.
Seeing through emptiness, movement and stillness graceful,
the spirit-pearl grants every wish.

---

**Drunk on the River Moon**
Primal qi swirls through the celestial pivot,
the Dipper’s handle turns the starry vault.
Sun and moon entwine, advancing and retreating,
fixing dawn, dusk, crescent, and full.
The four seasons cycle, yin and yang harmonize—
creation’s work supreme.
Vast and luminous, it crafts the myriad forms in perfect accord.
Divine function cleaves heaven and earth,
generation responds to the seasons—
the work of seven and nine converges.
Tiger coils, dragon coils, their roars a melody,
the riverbank’s voice wails in wind and wave.
Nurturing the divine embryo, surging in sacred transformation,
the Dharma-realm’s true nature unfurls.
The pearl in darkness gleams,
its radiant image boundless unfolds.

*Second Stanza*
The true heart, a hand’s breadth,
embraces the Great Ultimate, divides auspice,
mystic and yellow intertwine.
Within creation’s midst, the sage’s message—
sun and moon, tiger and dragon arrayed.
Beneath the crucible, crimson light,
diligently the civil and martial alternate,
advancing and retreating by the hour.
Refined into golden pistils,
the elixir’s body, ice-pure, densely clustered.
In the land of harmony, people rest,
the Heavenly Root silently aligns,
profound stillness delights in true suchness.
The pearl’s crystal light shoots through Ox and Dipper,
its bright radiance keen as frost and snow.
Ten thousand kalpas’ clouds gather,
lifetimes’ dust settles—
the heart’s dharma wholly extinguished in duality.
No words suffice—
suddenly, the bottom drops away, clarity dawns.

---

**Southern Village Song**
Duckweed and driftwood traverse heaven’s edge.
Cast off burdens, hollow out passions—all things void.
Rinsing stones, pillowing streams, sweetly nurturing vastness,
toiling diligently.
Plucking tortoise and snake, place them in the jade crucible.
Black waters yield golden pearls.
On winding shores, red frost moistens, anoints the soft.
The body’s crucible molds inch-long pellets—
the elixir’s wonder, without care.
Galloping through divine powers, the sun-and-moon flask.

*Second Stanza*

Advancing, retreating—hare and crow in harmony,
driven into the crucible of Heaven and Earth’s creation.
Lessening, increasing, the many follow measured motion—
joy in nature’s play.
Skillfully refining, the elixir congeals, the body never withers.

Nurturing essence, dust is transmuted to nothingness.
Unfettered, empty, and perfect—proud in the jade flask.
Responding to things, each encounter leaves no trace,
forms differ yet all
secretly cradle the mani-pearl that knows no night.

*Third Stanza*

The talismanic fire circles the celestial sphere,
increasing and decreasing without error to reach the four dhyanas.
Silently nurturing the iron ox that exhales jade pistils—
work complete.
Exchanging bones, restoring yang, one realizes the wondrous mystery.

Prajna arises from conditions,
transcending to the farther shore with ease.
Steadily steering the divine vessel home to Ultimate Bliss,
dust shed—
the pure heart unfurls a lotus rising from water.

*Fourth Stanza*

Silent as one who seems foolish,
a single qi swirls in the sun-and-moon crucible.
The mysterious female drives the meeting of the three natures—
congealing into softness.
Drunk on intoxication, the nature delights in itself.

Wind and moon cannot restrain it.
Heaven upon heaven turns the Dipper’s pivot.
The subtle workings of yin and yang shape wondrous delight—
joy in emotion.
A single stream of red light shines upon the Great Vastness.

*Fifth Stanza*

*The Great Dao in the Three Fields*

The Great Dao abides in the Three Fields—
know the One, then cease clinging to one side.
Through the two realms it flows within the square inch,
profound and mysterious—
the Three-in-One shapes form before the Emperor’s origin.

The deeper one drills, the more unyielding it grows;
the higher one gazes, the more boundless its transforming power.
Sight and hearing fail to grasp the limitless intent—
emptiness perfected.
Its wondrous body shines through ancient and present, whole and complete.

*Stay, Guest—*
*Awaken to arising and ceasing.*
In a sudden stroke, sever the wild horse’s frenzy and the monkey’s folly.
All conditions released at once,
one feels the true secret of the mysterious and yellow.
Returning to refuge, the heart is washed clean—
all is harmonized in balance.

The work of yin and yang blazes fierce.
Inhaling essence, absorbing purity,
one steals from the Void—
true beauty nurtures the seemingly dull.
Distinctions fade.
Qi meets spirit in communion,
forgetting form in true delight.
The ear is filled with pure sound,
a myriad streams in the silent void sigh deep.
The solitary yang transforms into an immortal realm,
offering forth immaculate whiteness.
Wind and light—pristine as ice and jade.
The spirit soars beyond things, roaming freely,
treading the void in pristine clarity.

Descending to the center,
one steals the harmonious qi of heaven and earth—
the foundation of the elixir’s creation.
The Mysterious Female assists the pivot of the mechanism.
Four Images and Three Wonders—
the ebb and flow of fortune and adversity,
lead and mercury drawn forth from Kan and Li.
Advancing and retreating in cycles,
the Jade Gate’s wind blows through the nine heavens.
Clouds move, rain falls,
irrigating the yellow sprout’s snowy flesh.
Five hues rise in radiant shade,
the fragrant beauty of two eights.
The Six Yang cauldron seethes,
firing times follow the celestial cycles.
Nurturing form to wholeness,
mist gathers, clouds withdraw—entering non-doing.

*Second Stanza*

Vast and profound, the spirit clear, the nature pure,
the body vigorous, lightly soaring.
Boundless, resplendent—light takes flight.
Moonlike, it dons the radiance of Li.
In a flourish, a thousand spirits shift in form,
wherever touched, each reveals its proper aspect.
Wisdom dispels delusion,
the breast claps with icy clarity—bound for Jasper Pool.
Auspicious guests gather in feast,
scattering rare fragrance,
mist curling within crimson curtains.
Joyous music accompanies,
celebrating with divine delight.
The unborn body’s state—
laughing freely, returning to the true realm’s favor.
Through kalpas, perfect illumination,
urging beyond the supreme, into the formless.

*Gazing Toward Penglai*

Pushing forth wondrous principle,
concealing function, manifesting through benevolence.
The spirit settled in profound darkness, heaven and earth merge—
doubt not the pure breeze of indistinct enlightenment.
The five qi preserve celestial truth.
The golden crucible seethes,
brilliant as newly wrought jade.
Nurtured through kalpas, the unimpeded form arises,
the three awakenings of the numinous source verify the whole body.
Pure and clear, the rabbit escapes sinking.

*Second Stanza*

The spirit stilled for long,
its workings enter non-doing.
All day, one fears lest it show the slightest sign—
like an infant, moving and resting in joyous ease.
Necessarily firm, the heart departs all.

No cutting off delusion,
yet truth requires no cultivation.
The hearts of truth and delusion belong to dust’s veil—
when the veil of dust is unstained, the nature is formless.
The pearl gleams, the mani jewel revealed.

*Third Stanza*

**The Hidden Dragon Moves**

The hidden dragon stirs,
unyielding, coiled in the sea’s abyssal source.
Black mists veil the three passes in deep concealment,
crimson clouds weave through nine winding peaks.
The jade crucible refines the golden elixir.

The precious vase is filled,
snow-white waves surge boundless.
Eight windows, four doors radiate sun and moon,
the six spirits flow free—earth and heaven expand.
The true realm inscribes true joy.

*Fourth Stanza*

True fire turns,
the five viscera’s qi simmer and seethe.
Yang subdues the six yins in hidden transformation,
essence transmutes to marrow, blood to essence.
White milk forms the body anew.

The primal spirit gathers,
at dawn it appears, preserving the body’s glory.
Golden bones replace the form—indestructible,
light scatters in ten thousand strands, radiant as dawn’s glow.
Cloud-steps traverse Penglai’s isles.

**Wuling Spring**

Fire and water intertwine in south and north,
metal and wood exchange west and east.
The embryo coalesces at the source, the imperial flourishing palace.
Through subtle workings, true achievement is wrought.

A steed gallops beyond the three isles,
nine bends, six oxen connect.
The dark pearl ferments, crimson through the body,
light and strong, merging in harmony.

*Second Stanza*

On the yin ridge, the two-eight medicinal sprouts are gathered,
plucked—snow-white golden blossoms.
The four-footed wu-wei crucible forges them,
the three natures unite in true crystal.

From the sea’s depths, breath blows the flameless fire,
tempering through countless refinements.
The ice-flesh is wrought, gleaming as white jade.
The spirit-sage’s visage, unbounded.

*Third Stanza*

The immortal’s Dao—from ancient times to now, it is man himself,
yet you fear your own heart is lost.
You say heaven is high, I say it is low.
Three inches make the ladder to heaven.

Nineteen such men never arrive,
separated as clouds from mud.
The wondrous secret pours forth—if you but trust and act,
merit and power align with heaven.

**Willow Tops Green**

The bitter sea stretches vast, drifting and tossing,
seeming as boundless as the northern ocean’s surging waves.
Multitudes sink, like fish at play,
endlessly chasing, drawn to and fro.

Adrift in throngs, hearts at ease—
how few transform into roc-like forms?
Once they ascend to the celestial pond,
wings spread through the clouds,
instantly transcending the supreme.

**Paired Swallows**

Circling sun and moon,
spring and autumn shift between flourishing and withering—
how many cycles have they woven?
Tang’s courts and Han’s palaces,
Chu’s gardens and Qin’s halls rise and fall.

The sea of love’s currents—what constancy holds them?
All vast and boundless, without birth or stagnation.
Startled awake from the kalpa’s dusty passions,
turning inward, we trace the root and stem.

**Luminous Wisdom**

Embracing the One, we grasp the Three.
The true heart moves heaven and earth,
Kan and Li merge in mutual aid.
Mists coalesce, enclosing,
purple veils and white blossoms guard the gate.

The pearl gestates in profound mystery, resplendent,
refining the spirit, shedding the cloud-soul like a cicada’s husk.
Entering and exiting the formless without hindrance,
permeating the three times in unity.

**Jade Terrace, First Tier**

Heat departs, cold arrives,
borne by the sun and moon’s ceaseless advance and retreat.
Spring and autumn alternate,
withering and flourishing succeed one another—
how many scenes have changed?

Life hurries on,
cutting short the waist, whitening the hair,
all to ninety and beyond.
Yet impermanence comes—
though gold and jade fill the coffers,
no remedy can save.

**Pondering**

Swiftly awaken, turn back with fierce resolve,
clearing the heart’s ground to nurture primordial yang.
Hands grasp heaven and earth,
the body births ten thousand transformations,
soaring through the empty realm.

Death and life are severed,
leaping free from the world’s net—
the true form, cool and clear.
The Dao’s essence flourishes,
attaining the three times with perfect clarity,
through the ages, majestic and bright.

**Moonlight Pure**

A single spark of spirit-light,
a thousand cycles of sinking,
wandering through the four births and six destinies.
Drowning in the bitter sea,
how often do we change our faces?

Chilled by the four great elements—rootless, illusory,
appearing and vanishing like shooting stars or lightning.
Endless—
the strange stench of coming and going,
the withering and flourishing of change.

Seeing through it all, we cling to nothing.
Awakening to the dream-butterfly, the lamp-moth,
we transcend birth’s monopoly.
Tightly sealing the mysterious pass,
tempering the inch-heart through a thousand refinements.

Refined, the primal origin’s purity is revealed,
expanding into earth, ascending into heaven—embodied.
All-pervading—
defying spiritual powers with boldness,
cooled by the pure breeze’s fan.

**Orioles Through Willows**

Gazing at heaven’s expanse,
toward the three mountains and four seas,
mists and winds converge.
Metal, wood, and profound darkness,
clouds gather in an instant,
the six trigrams’ fire records advance in secret.

The seven returns’ work must be urgently refined,
the elixir’s essence fragrant as orchids.
At this stage, ghosts and spirits revere,
the three corpses are not permitted near.

Worldly passions shatter into dust.
The flames of ignorance and wrath are dashed,
turned to cold embers.
Wisdom’s treasury opens, the spirit shines,
claiming the Upper Clarity’s selected halls,
a name among the pure and outstanding.

The true form towers,
striding the void’s borders,
radiant with rosy clouds.
The body manifests nine suns,
transcending the dust—trust in this.

**Hundred Treasures Adorned**

Clouds and water—leisurely sentiments,
pine and bamboo—elegant conduct,
delving into the Dao’s true secrets.
Sweeping away mist and smoke,
forging the will like iron.

Unmoved by the joy of bamboo basket and gourd,
expanding the foolish valley,
cultivating brightness through plain simplicity.
Opening the heart’s breadth,
seizing inspiration in wild song,
brandishing the brush across the paper’s expanse.

Tiger and dragon roar in fury,
coiling ten thousand fathoms,
spraying resplendent words,
unfolding brocade’s pristine beauty.

In stillness, the work deepens,
the spirit’s use reveals utmost subtlety.
The nature-moon, thus thus—
its light fully revealed,
illuminating ancient and modern, round yet unbroken.

Merging with the formless qi,
spanning the eight directions,
the true body knows no distinction.

**Calming the Storm**

The work refines, the heart opens, wisdom’s treasury rounds.
A single point of numinous brightness surpasses the moon’s grace.
Beyond things, towering—alone in mystery,
neither empty nor existent, its form defies description.

Everywhere, it fully extends the unimpeded form,
shattering the void, boundless.
Joyous—liberated from the wheel of rebirth this very moment,
the achievement ascends.
Nine mysteries transcend the Supreme Tenuity’s heavens.

*Second Stanza*

Awakening binds the kalpa’s cool, vast cause.
A life of simplicity rises above the clamorous dust.
Every thing, every phenomenon—detached from the heart,
thoughts purified.
Diligently nurturing the primal spirit in the empty valley.

Meeting things with harmonious light, following virtue’s handle,
responding without fixed form, embracing heaven’s truth.
Vast and unobstructed, mastering the three mysteries’ essence,
treasuring the heart.
The Daoist’s talent and temperament—exceptionally pure and fresh.

*Third Stanza*

An inch of cinnabar heart, crushed and refined.
Wielding the wisdom-sea, stilling the winds and waves.
In the forest’s joy, content with plain sustenance,
harmonious.
Opening the heart-moon to illuminate the sahā world.

Within, the three accumulations of precepts are complete,
the body at ease, rich in the six pāramitās.
Hidden or manifest, the spirit roams, utterly free,
nowhere and everywhere.

Beyond the azure heavens, carefree and wandering.
*Mo Yu Er*
Nurturing detachment, dreams of indolence startle worldly airs;
floating clouds of wealth and honor—empty posturing.
Raising high the jeweled sword, its frosty mien cold,
the strife of petty minds all swept away.
Tamed are the ape and horse.
Yet when worldly affairs arise, the heart’s snares tangle and disturb.
A breast of ice, the mind’s cave luminous.
Delighting in pure realms, in action or retreat,
nurturing the sprouts of goodness,
knowing how much to drink from the water’s flow.

True qi swirls and billows,
the heart-pearl of the steadfast sea gleams bright.
Solemn and still beyond the clouds,
leaving the dust, auspicious signs conceive the cinnabar foundation.
Radiant as the rainbow’s arc, the spirit’s light,
crystalline and clear.
Shattering the ancient gloom of the crossroads,
illuminating the zenith of the dhyāna heavens.
The soul soars into boundless distance.
Freely treading the pure and subtle,
roaming the Dharma realms,
manifesting in flawless demeanor.

*Tune: Mu Lan Hua*
Qi harmonizes and blends, the wind’s charm keen.
Dragon coiled, tiger encircling,
the wu courtyard’s interlacing.
Gentle warmth lingers, the body entwined with spring snow.
The spirit’s light moonlike,
shining through the nine heavens.
Piercing the delusive clouds, the demonic ranks dissolve.
The three terraces and six viscera,
the eight passes—pure as ice.
The pure yang body attains the secret of non-doing.
Roaming the Dharma realms,
the Daoist’s sentiment—exquisitely pure.

*Liu Yao Ling*
Beholding heaven’s creation,
advancing to emulate the reclusive and serene.
Upholding the mean of firmness and yielding,
the five aggregates delight in non-doing.
Nurturing the nine suns’ auspicious signs,
the Kun palace’s Kan and Li conjoined.
At midday, the resplendent phoenix
soars above the river’s bend,
seeking the black turtle in the depths of ten thousand waves.
Purple mists shroud the mountain’s peak,
messages congeal in icy flesh.
Majestic and cool, the body’s bearing,
the six spirits at ease.
The three luminaries’ radiance unobstructed,
the sea’s edge a haven for carefree dwelling.
Amid the clouds, reclining at ease,
joyous and unbound,
the old visage—bright and expansive.

*Love for Reed Flowers*
The heart opens, five pairs forgotten,
the nature freed, six passions severed.
Qi, spirit, form—transforming,
the head’s crown empty, blood takes flight.
The banner of merit gleams with cinnabar’s luster,
the yang soul roused, its might fierce.
Unchanging from beginning to end, the true form revealed,
pervading without inside or out,
its appearance beyond distinction.
Born from arising and ceasing,
the body of purity—unbounded,
image-free, heaven’s midst pierced through.
The eye of true Dharma ultimately,
plucking the finest dust from the brows.
Radiance unfurls, ten thousand ages’ purity immaculate.
Round and bright, all things manifest,
lucid as the moon’s flaw.

chunks.original_text: 会真集 经名：会真集。 元超然予王吉昌撰。 五卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞真部方法类。 会真集序 夫易广矣大矣，其无体也。 始於一气，即道也。 易有三义：不易也，变易也，简易也？ 不易者，独立而不改。 变易者，四时更代也。 简易者，天地简易也。 六爻者，内卦谓之贞，天地人为之三才之定体也。 因而重之曰悔，谓吉凶悔吝生乎动者也。 下二爻为地，中二爻为人，上二爻为天，上下无位。 二五本以人事论之，故称见龙飞龙，利见大人。 三四本天地之位，不称龙。 以人事君子呼之，即天人相通之象也。 乾坤，天地之德也。 以刚柔相配，生三男三女，分制五材，谓之五行，代天地行事也。 后生六十四卦，分布一年三百八十四爻，大约统以年月气候日时，一日变十二卦。 一人为万物之灵，其性命全，与天地同体。 惟圣知圣，仁者见之谓之仁，知者见之谓之知，能斡运於自身者，是谓养道之士也。 后人判教有三，以《易》为真玄，以《老子》为虚玄，以《庄子》为谈玄。 其说则异，至於玄则同归，非常人所通晓，惟神仙能之。 去岁春，余於青义清神观，会识吉昌王先生，号曰超然子。 与之语，咳唾珠玉，呼吸烟霞，混三玄而讲义。 惜乎别之速矣。 双凫西迈，俄变星霜，使老夫夙夕不忘。 今者二仙子得得来云溪，倒屐出迎，一者写唐梁振之，一者纷南梁之秀，皆故人也。 延之尚座，茗饮小会，坐中乃举其师超然子所着《会真文集》，欲缕板通布於四方，请老拙作序引。 袖出其文，老夫从首至尾，历观其词语，以去岁一会之语话也。 考其图绘咏歌，皆出自胸臆中，埏坛轮旋，调和大块，心腹间炉鞴煅炼混元，明七八九六之老少，水火木金土之生成。 王子晋所谓颠倒五行，推移八卦，正谓此也。 非神仙，孰能与此乎。 若遍行於世，使学道之士如秉烛入於暗室也。 钦二仙子能扬师之美，可谓不忘本也。 故不敢违命，略序其实於卷首。 魏南云溪闲老扬志朴序。 会真集卷之一 〔周易象数图说〕 太　极

**The *Huizhen Collection***

**Title:** *Huizhen Collection*. Composed by Wang Jichang, styled Chaoran. Five fascicles. Source text: *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongzhen* Section, Methods Category.

**Preface to the *Huizhen Collection***

The *Book of Changes* is vast and boundless, formless in its essence. It begins with the singular *qi*—this is the Dao. The *Changes* embodies three principles: the unchanging, the mutable, and the simple.

The unchanging is that which stands alone and never alters. The mutable is the succession of the four seasons. The simple is the effortless order of heaven and earth.

The six lines of a hexagram: the inner trigram is called "purity," the fixed structure of heaven, earth, and humanity as the Three Powers. When doubled, it is called "regret," for fortune and misfortune, regret and humiliation arise from movement.

The lower two lines represent earth, the middle two humanity, and the upper two heaven. The top and bottom positions hold no rank. The second and fifth lines are discussed in terms of human affairs, hence the phrases "the dragon appears" and "the dragon soars," and "it is beneficial to see the great person." The third and fourth lines occupy the positions of heaven and earth and are not called "dragons." When addressed in human terms as the "noble person," this reflects the resonance between heaven and humanity.

*Qian* and *Kun* are the virtues of heaven and earth. Through the interplay of hardness and softness, they give birth to three sons and three daughters, governing the Five Agents—these are the Five Phases, acting on behalf of heaven and earth. Later, the sixty-four hexagrams emerged, distributing 384 lines across a year, roughly corresponding to the cycles of years, months, seasons, days, and hours, with twelve hexagrams changing each day.

Humankind is the spirit of the myriad things, its nature and destiny complete, one in body with heaven and earth. Only the sagely know the sagely; the benevolent see it as benevolence, the wise see it as wisdom. Those who can harmonize and direct it within themselves are called cultivators of the Dao.

Later scholars divided teachings into three, regarding the *Book of Changes* as the "true mystery," the *Laozi* as the "void mystery," and the *Zhuangzi* as the "discursive mystery." Though their explanations differ, they converge in mystery, beyond the grasp of ordinary people—only immortals can fathom it.

Last spring, at the Qingyi Pure Spirit Abbey, I met Master Wang Jichang, styled Chaoranzi. In conversation, his words flowed like pearls and jade, his breath like mist and clouds, as he expounded the three mysteries. Alas, our parting came too swiftly. Like a pair of wild ducks flying west, time passed in the blink of an eye, and I have not forgotten him day or night.

Now, two immortal youths have arrived at Yunxi, and I rushed out to greet them, sandals askew. One is the reincarnation of Liang Zhen of the Tang, the other a scion of the southern Liang—both old friends. I invited them to the honored seat, and over tea, they mentioned their teacher Chaoranzi’s work, the *Huizhen Collection*, wishing to carve blocks and disseminate it widely. They asked this old rustic to write a preface.

From his sleeve, he produced the text. From beginning to end, I perused its words, recalling our conversation of last year. Examining its diagrams, poems, and songs, all sprang from his heart and mind—shaping the altar, revolving the wheel, harmonizing the great cosmos, forging the Primordial within his innermost being. He clarifies the ages of the seven, eight, nine, and six, and the generation and completion of water, fire, wood, metal, and earth.

This is what Prince Wang Zijian meant by "inverting the Five Phases and shifting the Eight Trigrams." Who but an immortal could achieve this? If it spreads throughout the world, seekers of the Dao will be like those holding a torch in a dark room.

I admire the two immortal youths for propagating their teacher’s excellence—they have not forgotten their roots. Thus, I dare not refuse their request and have briefly set forth these facts at the beginning of the scroll.

Preface by Yang Zhipu, the Leisurely Old Man of Wei’s Southern Yunxi.

**Fascicle One of the *Huizhen Collection***
**[Diagrams and Explanations of the Symbolism and Numerology of the *Zhouyi*]**
**The Supreme Ultimate**

The Supreme Ultimate is the designation of the Limitless, yet it cannot be named. Its qi, form, and substance remain undifferentiated in primordial chaos. Within it reside the fifty-five numbers, containing the Two Modes, Three Luminaries, Four Images, and Five Phases—all complete yet without form. This is what the *Laozi* refers to as "a thing chaotically formed." The *Jade Inscription* states: "Before the separation of the Dark and Yellow, the qi’s appearance was dim and obscure." How can those who study the Dao fail to know the origin of the singular qi, the ancestor of the myriad things?

The numbers generate the Five Phases:
Water: one (☰ Qian, Jia)

Once the Five Ultimates were divided and the Two Modes first separated, the Four Images then subtly arose, and the Five Phases secretly took form. Within them, the qi’s hues shifted and transformed, their shapes and images becoming distinct. After a million years of dim obscurity, the qi turned black. Black corresponds to the image of Water, whose generative number is one. One is the beginning of the Qian’s origin, the root of the Eight Trigrams, and gives rise to Jia. Jia is the first of the Five Phases and the origin of the ten celestial stems. Thus, in this primordial era, the sages observed its celestial patterns and inscribed the heavenly tally, recording the celestial patterns. Later, worthy successors reverently upheld this, marking the celestial origin and establishing the calendar through the arrangement of lines. From that time onward, the reckoning of years and seasons spread and became manifest.

Fire: two

chunks.original_text: 黑气一百万年复变成赤色。 赤者火象，其生数二，乃巽卦之始，而生辛也。 木三 赤气一百万年变成青苍色。 青者木象，其生数三，乃艮卦之始，而生丙也。 金四 青气一百万年复变成白色。 白者金象，其生数四，乃坤卦之始，而生癸也。 士五 白气一百万年又变成黄色。 黄者土象，其生数五，乃离卦之始，而生己也。 五行成数 夫五行从生数至成数，谓一三五数成阳九，甲丙主之而为客。 缘中央五数离己土，合於甲，加之水一，得成数六，而下降生坤乙，故先动而为客也。 二四数成阴六，辛癸主之而为主也。 又五土加於火二，得成数七，而上升生震庚。 乙与庚合，南北交迁，故后动而为主也。 其水一火二土成十，生坎戊。 又火生数巽辛，随己土合於木三艮丙，得成数八，而生兑丁。 又水生数乾甲，亦就中宫土五数，合於金四坤癸，得成数金九，而生乾壬。 丁壬交合，东西互换，此所以运两地三天造化，推阳九阴六生成，变干转支轮，分飞伏纳甲。 具二升一降，抽添水火，明三匿四浮，互换木金。 是以道朴散万化门基，妙用彰千灵降瑞。 凡修真之子，可不穷阴阳之祖哉。 火六 从五土加水一，得成数六，而生坤乙。 火七 又五土加火二，得成数七，而生震庚。 木八 又五土加木三，得成数八，而生兑丁。 金九 又五土加金四→ 得成数九，而生乾壬。 土十 又五土加五土，得成数十，而生坎戊。 乃得八卦，俱备十干方全。 混融而母怀子腹，子隐母胎，未能分别也。 交互成十 夫乾坤配偶，而生成数全，分阳降阴升，浮沉颊倒； 左旋右转，上下连绵，五位相得，而各有合。 一九成十，壬甲相见，乾偶於坤而生坎，坎藏甲乙。 四六成十，乙癸同迁，坤配於乾而生兑，兑藏癸壬。 交互成十 又三七成十，庚丙相见，乾偶於坤而生震，震藏丙丁。 二八成十，丁辛相见，坤配於乾而生离，离藏庚辛。 土象自交　 坎戊 又离纳己而得五，坎纳戊而得十，共得一十五数。 其数得天地之中数，其位得天地之中位，所以无配偶而自相合也。 四象生八卦 夫二仪生四象，四象之中，坎成数六，本卦存三，外有三数，而生乾，纳壬不纳癸，乾坤偶而癸纳於坤。 兑成数九，本卦存三，外有六数，而生坤，纳乙不纳甲，坤乾配合而甲纳於乾。 离成数七，本卦存三，外有四数，而生巽，纳辛不纳庚，震巽交而庚纳於震。 震成数八，本卦存三，外有五数，而生良。 纳丙不纳丁，艮兑交而丁纳兑。 是以明颠倒五行，定相推变化，遂分生，成八卦，具形体，昭彰证。 中男产老阳，是金向水中出。 少女诞老阴，是土从金裹生。 惟木生於火，中女降巽辛。 而土生於木，长男挺艮丙。 以是知明乾坤刚柔动静，述震巽鼓润风雷，仍丙丁胥会隔角，明分振飞伏移宫。 生成数备，乃体更反复，魂变归游，隐显还元，升沉摄迹，己上八干神，为之三换位。 其有戊己无象而独摄，四傍居位而亦无配偶。 以己为阴，纳於中女离卦，以戊为阳，纳於中男坎卦。 得十干方全，数成奇偶，显一时造化，动静合真。 足表观天之道，执天之行尽矣。 凡修真者，宜顺考爻辞，明循卦体，夺上下阴阳升降，穷生成消息往来。 精专内巧之心，冥尽日新之变，得鼎中悔吝不生，至精气降，金汞凝形，指日结神丹，其如视诸掌矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The black qi transformed again after a million years, turning crimson. Crimson corresponds to the image of Fire, whose generative number is two. Two is the beginning of the Xun trigram and gives rise to Xin.

Wood: three
After a million years, the crimson qi turned verdant. Verdant corresponds to the image of Wood, whose generative number is three. Three is the beginning of the Gen trigram and gives rise to Bing.

Metal: four
After another million years, the verdant qi transformed into white. White corresponds to the image of Metal, whose generative number is four. Four is the beginning of the Kun trigram and gives rise to Gui.

Earth: five
After a million years, the white qi turned yellow. Yellow corresponds to the image of Earth, whose generative number is five. Five is the beginning of the Li trigram and gives rise to Ji.

The Completion Numbers of the Five Phases
From the generative numbers to the completion numbers of the Five Phases: the odd numbers one, three, and five sum to the yang nine, governed by Jia and Bing, serving as the guest. As the central five of Earth (Li Ji) combines with Jia and the Water of one, it reaches the completion number six, descending to generate Kun Yi, thus moving first as the guest. The even numbers two and four sum to the yin six, governed by Xin and Gui, serving as the host. Further, the five of Earth added to the Fire of two reaches the completion number seven, ascending to generate Zhen Geng. Yi and Geng unite, exchanging north and south, thus moving later as the host. Water (one) and Fire (two) with Earth sum to ten, generating Kan Wu. Fire’s generative number (Xun Xin) follows Earth’s Ji to combine with Wood’s three (Gen Bing), reaching the completion number eight and generating Dui Ding. Water’s generative number (Qian Jia) also joins the central Earth’s five with Metal’s four (Kun Gui), reaching the completion number nine and generating Qian Ren. Ding and Ren unite, exchanging east and west. Thus, the transformations of two earths and three heavens are set in motion, reckoning the yang nine and yin six in generation and completion, revolving the stems and branches, distinguishing the soaring and hidden, and incorporating the Jia. With two ascending and one descending, water and fire are drawn and replenished; three are illuminated while four are concealed, and wood and metal interchange. Hence, the primordial Dao disperses as the foundation of the myriad transformations, its wondrous workings manifesting in the descent of a thousand spirits. How can those who cultivate the truth not delve into the origins of yin and yang?

Fire: six
From the five of Earth added to the Water of one, reaching the completion number six, generating Kun Yi.

Fire: seven
From the five of Earth added to the Fire of two, reaching the completion number seven, generating Zhen Geng.

Wood: eight
From the five of Earth added to the Wood of three, reaching the completion number eight, generating Dui Ding.

Metal: nine
From the five of Earth added to the Metal of four, reaching the completion number nine, generating Qian Ren.

Earth: ten
From the five of Earth added to the five of Earth, reaching the completion number ten, generating Kan Wu. Thus, the Eight Trigrams are complete, and the ten celestial stems are fully arrayed. They blend and merge, the mother embracing the child’s womb, the child concealed within the mother’s body, yet to be distinguished.

Interchange to Form Ten
As Qian and Kun pair, their completion numbers are fulfilled. Yang descends and yin ascends, floating and sinking, reversing and intertwining; rotating left and right, connecting above and below, the five positions interact, each finding its union. One and nine form ten: Ren and Jia meet, Qian pairs with Kun to generate Kan, which conceals Jia and Yi. Four and six form ten: Yi and Gui shift together, Kun pairs with Qian to generate Dui, which conceals Gui and Ren.

Interchange to Form Ten
Three and seven form ten: Geng and Bing meet, Qian pairs with Kun to generate Zhen, which conceals Bing and Ding. Two and eight form ten: Ding and Xin meet, Kun pairs with Qian to generate Li, which conceals Geng and Xin.

Earth’s Image Self-Unites
Kan Wu: Li incorporates Ji to obtain five, Kan incorporates Wu to obtain ten, together summing to fifteen. This number attains the mean of heaven and earth, its position occupying the center of heaven and earth, thus requiring no pairing but uniting itself.

The Four Images Generate the Eight Trigrams
From the Two Modes arise the Four Images. Within the Four Images, Kan’s completion number is six; its original trigram retains three, with three external numbers generating Qian, incorporating Ren but not Gui, as Qian and Kun pair and Gui is incorporated into Kun. Dui’s completion number is nine; its original trigram retains three, with six external numbers generating Kun, incorporating Yi but not Jia, as Kun and Qian unite and Jia is incorporated into Qian. Li’s completion number is seven; its original trigram retains three, with four external numbers generating Xun, incorporating Xin but not Geng, as Zhen and Xun interact and Geng is incorporated into Zhen. Zhen’s completion number is eight; its original trigram retains three, with five external numbers generating Gen, incorporating Bing but not Ding, as Gen and Dui interact and Ding is incorporated into Dui. Thus, the Five Phases are inverted and defined, their mutual transformations and changes clearly distinguished. The Eight Trigrams take form, their structures manifest and evident.

The middle son produces the old yang: Metal emerges from within Water. The youngest daughter gives birth to the old yin: Earth arises from within Metal. Only Wood is born of Fire, the middle daughter descending as Xun Xin. And Earth is born of Wood, the eldest son emerging as Gen Bing. From this, we discern the firmness and yielding, movement and stillness of Qian and Kun; the stirring and moistening of Zhen and Xun, wind and thunder; the meeting and separation of Bing and Ding at the corners; the clear divisions of soaring and hidden, shifting palaces. With the completion numbers established, the body reverses and cycles, the hun-soul transforms and roams, concealment and manifestation return to their origin, ascent and descent gather their traces. The eight celestial stems above undergo three positional shifts. Wu and Ji, formless and solitary, govern the four directions yet lack pairing. Ji, as yin, is incorporated into the middle daughter Li; Wu, as yang, is incorporated into the middle son Kan. Thus, the ten celestial stems are complete, their numbers forming odd and even, revealing the transformations of a single moment, the union of movement and stillness with the true. This fully expresses the Dao of observing heaven and mastering its movements. Those who cultivate the truth should diligently study the line texts, clearly follow the trigram structures, seize the ascent and descent of yin and yang above and below, and thoroughly explore the ebb and flow of generation and completion. With focused and inwardly refined intent, they will fathom the ceaseless changes of each day. When no regrets arise within the crucible, the purest qi descends, gold and mercury congeal into form, and the divine elixir is swiftly achieved—clear as the palm of one’s hand.

The Essentials of Stem Conjunction and the Return of the Eight Trigrams

The ten celestial stems and eight trigrams embody the five phases and four images, generating transformations and giving rise to completion. They divide north and south, east and west, then return and interchange. Within them, Kan and Li serve as gates and portals, while Qian and Kun act as the pivot and vessel of the crucible. They propel the union of yin and yang, dispatching the two qi to race forth. With each descent and ascent, the stem spirits shift position; through the convergence of the Two Modes and Three Unions, the trigram images submit to their origin.

Those who study the Dao must embody heaven and earth’s transformative workings and drive the sun and moon to share the same palace. With each inhalation and exhalation, a single celestial cycle is completed; with each gathering and dispersion, life and destiny are determined. As Laozi said: *"The gate of the Mysterious Female—this is called the root of heaven and earth."*

When the yang tally is to move, Kun pursues Qian, emerging from the left; when yin holds authority, Qian follows Kun, responding from the right. Their ceaseless coming and going aligns with the principle of stem conjunction and trigram correspondence.

The formula states: Through exhalation, the number seven is formed—Li as fire, where true water descends within. Ji unites with Jia, and Jia, rejoicing, ascends, flying into the divine palace. Through inhalation, the number six is formed—Kan as water, where true fire rises within. Wu unites with Gui, and Gui, delighted, descends into the elixir chamber. Ding and Ren conjoin, returning to Li and Ji, like mountains and marshes exchanging qi, phoenix dancing and crow soaring. Yi and Geng gaze longingly, turning to Kan and Wu, like wind and thunder clashing, hare glowing and toad shining.

Thus, the four images return to the golden crucible, and the five phases gather into the jade furnace. Bing and Xin manifest, meeting Qian and Kun, uniting with Wu and Ji, and circulating the ten stems to return to the origin. When gathered, they are like grasping ten fingers; when dispersed, each reverts to its proper place.

**Upright**　　　　　　**Inverted**

chunks.original_text: 夫五行颠倒者，谓坎为水，水生金，是生乾金，藏甲乙，飞伏木，长生在亥。 兑为金，金生土，是生坤土，藏壬癸，飞伏水，长生在申。 离为火，火生木，是生巽木，藏庚辛，飞伏金，长生在巳。 震为木，木生土，是生艮土，藏丁丙，飞伏火，长生在寅。 其有戊己，独中央，兼旺四季，寄於西南坤地，是土正旺之处，长生在於申也。 谓呼而阳干顺行，吸而阴干逆转，阴阳逆顺聚散，隐於成数。 成数者，天元之动气也。 五　　　　　　　　　　行 干　　　　　　　　　　合 夫天地初分，阴阳析位，乃天分五气，地列五行。 五行定位，布政於四方； 五气分流，散之於十干。 其干神移位，配偶相生，形象分着而各有合，派天元五气而成真五行也。 凡修真者，当先穷干轮互换之机，次晓配合生成之象，此乃结括性命之本，造化大丹之基。 谓基本立则大道生矣。 甲己真土 夫癸生东方甲乙木神，乃水生木戊为甲父，将中央阴土己，配与甲为妻，甲己合而成真土。 乙庚真金 夫己生西方庚辛金神，乃土生金甲为庚父，将东方阴木乙，配与庚为妻，乙庚合而成真金。 丙辛真水 夫乙生南方丙丁火神，乃木生火庚为丙父，将西方阴金辛，配与丙为妻，丙辛合而成真水。 丁壬真木 夫辛生北方壬癸水神，乃金生水丙为壬父，将南方阴火丁，配与壬为妻，丁壬合而成真木。 戊癸真火 夫丁生中央戊己土神，乃火生土壬为戊父，将北方阴水癸，配与戊为妻，戊癸合而成真火。 揭此为用，周而复始。 木金间隔 夫学道者，究性命之本，穷造化之根，辩木金间隔之因，明水火抽添之理，达阴阳显伏，晓魂魄浮沉。 所谓木中隐金间隔者，盖木为阳魂，乃东方震卦为体，震纳庚为坤卦之长男，是一阳二阴，乃为阳魂，本合上升，为二阴伏一阳，而不能升也。 在人之五脏为肝，沉於肺金之下，为肝有庚金间隔，肝之真性虽欲上浮，奈庚属阴魄，能盗阳魂，使阳不得升，所以沉於下也。 若夺得玄机，运周天火符，千日无差，炼尽肝中庚魄，肝还祖性，纯而不杂，自然升矣。 泠然子云：请问肝中何物是金？ 对曰：肝生而入水即沉，为沉者金也。 木金相混，其色乃紫。 紫者，金也。 故沉而在下，遇火烹煎而熟，肝自浮而在上，其色变青，号曰还元。 适其本性，乃得魂神凝静，而不乱也。 所谓金中隐木间隔者，盖金藏阴魄，属西方，兑卦为体，本合沉而反浮者，何也？ 缘兑为乾之少女，一阴二阳也。 为一阴不能伏二阳，故浮而在上也。 兑乃庚金，乙与庚合，妇从夫室，而金为主。 金者属肺，被乙木浮，而金在水之上也。 若夺得周天火候，烹炼千日无差，炼尽肺中之木，乃得不杂而显其金之本体，自然沉而下也。 泠然子曰：请问肺中何物是木？ 对曰； 肺生而色红，白者木也。 故入水而浮，若遇火烹而熟，肺自沉而在下，其色变紫，得返其本性之真魄，安而寿命延矣。 金木入火辩宾主 夫金木相混，遇火则体性还元，要木中去金，金中去木。 既二物同炼，何木中独去其金而存其木，金中独去其木而存其金乎？ 盖谓木中去金者，为木有本像而为主，金隐木中，金色浮而为客。 遇火烹之，则先去其客，而存其主也。 金中去木者，为金有刚体而为主，木在金中，木性柔而为客，遇火烹之，则主在而客去矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The inversion of the five phases is thus: Kan as water generates metal, producing Qian-metal, which conceals Jia and Yi, with flying and latent wood, its phase of growth beginning in Hai. Dui as metal generates earth, producing Kun-earth, which conceals Ren and Gui, with flying and latent water, its phase of growth beginning in Shen. Li as fire generates wood, producing Xun-wood, which conceals Geng and Xin, with flying and latent metal, its phase of growth beginning in Si. Zhen as wood generates earth, producing Gen-earth, which conceals Ding and Bing, with flying and latent fire, its phase of growth beginning in Yin.

As for Wu and Ji, they alone govern the center, flourishing in all four seasons, lodged in the southwest Kun-earth—the place where earth is most vigorous, its phase of growth beginning in Shen. This is called: with exhalation, the yang stems move in sequence; with inhalation, the yin stems reverse their course. Yin and yang, reversing and advancing, gather and disperse, concealed within the completion numbers. The completion numbers are the dynamic qi of the celestial origin.

**Five Phases**　　　　　　**Stems Conjoin**

When heaven and earth first divided, yin and yang separated into their positions. Heaven distributed the five qi, and earth arrayed the five phases. The five phases established their positions, governing the four directions; the five qi branched forth, scattering into the ten stems. The stem spirits shift their positions, pairing and generating one another, their forms and images distinctly manifesting their unions, deriving from the celestial origin’s five qi to become the true five phases.

All who cultivate the Dao must first thoroughly investigate the mechanism of stem-wheel interchange, then comprehend the images of their generative unions—this is the foundation for binding essence and life, the basis for the great elixir of transformation. When the root is established, the great Dao arises.

**Jia-Ji True Earth**
Gui generates the wood spirits Jia and Yi in the east—water generating wood, with Wu as Jia’s father. The central yin-earth Ji is given to Jia as wife, and Jia-Ji unite to form true earth.

**Yi-Geng True Metal**
Ji generates the metal spirits Geng and Xin in the west—earth generating metal, with Jia as Geng’s father. The eastern yin-wood Yi is given to Geng as wife, and Yi-Geng unite to form true metal.

**Bing-Xin True Water**
Yi generates the fire spirits Bing and Ding in the south—wood generating fire, with Geng as Bing’s father. The western yin-metal Xin is given to Bing as wife, and Bing-Xin unite to form true water.

**Ding-Ren True Wood**
Xin generates the water spirits Ren and Gui in the north—metal generating water, with Bing as Ren’s father. The southern yin-fire Ding is given to Ren as wife, and Ding-Ren unite to form true wood.

**Wu-Gui True Fire**
Ding generates the earth spirits Wu and Ji in the center—fire generating earth, with Ren as Wu’s father. The northern yin-water Gui is given to Wu as wife, and Wu-Gui unite to form true fire.

Revealed thus for application, cycling without end.

**Wood and Metal Interspersed**
Those who study the Dao must probe the root of essence and life, fathom the origin of transformation, discern the cause of wood and metal’s interspersion, clarify the principles of water and fire’s extraction and supplementation, grasp yin and yang’s manifest and latent states, and understand the floating and sinking of hun and po.

The interspersion of metal within wood: wood is yang-hun, embodied in the eastern Zhen trigram, which receives Geng as Kun’s eldest son—a single yang with two yins, thus yang-hun. It should ascend, but with two yins suppressing one yang, it cannot rise. In the human five viscera, this is the liver, submerged beneath lung-metal. The liver contains Geng-metal’s interspersion: though the liver’s true nature desires to float upward, Geng, as yin-po, steals the yang-hun, preventing its ascent and keeping it below. If one seizes the mysterious mechanism, circulating the fire tally of the celestial cycle for a thousand days without error, refining away the Geng-po within the liver, the liver returns to its ancestral nature, pure and unadulterated, and naturally ascends.

Leng Ranzi asked: "What in the liver is metal?"
Answer: "When the liver is born and enters water, it sinks—what sinks is metal. Wood and metal intermingle, its color becoming purple. Purple is metal. Thus it sinks below. When met with fire’s refining, it matures, the liver floats above, its color turning green, called *returning to the origin*. It regains its original nature, and the hun-spirit congeals, undisturbed."

The interspersion of wood within metal: metal conceals yin-po, belonging to the west, embodied in the Dui trigram. It should sink, yet instead floats—why? Dui is Qian’s youngest daughter, one yin with two yangs. The single yin cannot suppress the two yangs, so it floats above. Dui is Geng-metal; Yi and Geng unite, the wife following the husband’s chamber, with metal as the host. Metal is the lungs, but Yi-wood floats it, so metal lies above water. If one seizes the fire tally of the celestial cycle, refining for a thousand days without error, refining away the wood within the lungs, it becomes unadulterated, revealing metal’s original body, and naturally sinks.

Leng Ranzi asked: "What in the lungs is wood?"
Answer: "When the lungs are born, their color is red, but white is wood. Thus they float in water. When met with fire’s refining and matured, the lungs sink below, their color turning purple, returning to the true po of their original nature, settled and prolonging life."

**Metal and Wood in Fire: Discerning Host and Guest**
When metal and wood intermingle, fire restores their original natures. One must remove metal from wood and wood from metal. Since both are refined together, why is metal alone removed from wood while wood remains, and wood alone removed from metal while metal remains?

Removing metal from wood: wood has its original form as host, while metal, hidden within, is a floating guest in color. When refined by fire, the guest departs first, preserving the host. Removing wood from metal: metal has its rigid body as host, while wood within is soft and a guest. When refined by fire, the host remains while the guest departs.

chunks.original_text: 凡修真之士，当明金木锻炼之因，究宾主存亡之理，凭火候加减无差，铅汞抽添依数，自不日而丹成矣。 平叔注曰：养丹无火，似抱胎母死，久而无功，徒劳役也。 与金木得火而后辩者，理何异哉。 水火既济未济 夫水火之性，递相含孕。 水中有火，火中有水。 所谓水中有火者，何也？ 盖水属北方坎卦，乃阴中抱阳，谓水能照物者，即真火也。 水於人五脏为肾，肾藏精，精为火也。 谓火中有水者，何也？ 盖火属南方离卦，乃阳中抱阴也。 谓火中心黑者，即真水也。 火於人五脏为心，心主血，血为水也。 《易》曰：一水在火上，既济； 火在水上，未济。 平叔注曰：水中三火聚，火内水煎烹。 凡修真者，凭法象调和阴阳，钤键契之潜化，令水火升降，合既未抽添，自然鼎内铅汞凝结，而得丹成，则金光满室矣。 水火升降因土 夫《易》称：水流湿，火就燥，无识而相感，明自然之理也。 且水曰润下，火曰炎上，因何水火既济，水在上而火在下？ 盖坎水有火者，为坎纳戊为阳，清而为精，化清阳之气，能上升变为真水也。 离火有水者，为离纳己为阴，浊而为血，化重浊之气，能下降而变为真火也。 谓水火者，天元之真气，而生於脾。 脾神专权造化，独中央，斡运四傍，上升下降，随呼吸而来往。 夫天元气动，一息而有五者，潜契五行也。 《易》曰：天数五，地数六，乃阴阳之中数。 中数谓土也。 《参同契》曰：土旺四季，罗络始终，青赤白黑，各居一方，中宫所禀，戊己之功。 又平叔曰：四象五行全藉土。 谓坎离不得戊己中气往来升降，终不生产神丹矣。 坎离气变还元 夫心中藏汞，肾内隐铅，二物如何取用？ 盖五行颠倒术，真火变神水，铅汞化游魂，呼吸随风起，自然成其造化也。 谓天元气动於肾，乃坎戊为阳，一呼而动之有五。 地元气动於心，乃离己为阴，一吸而动之有五。 阴阳气动，数合成十。 《易》曰：天九地十，戊己自合也。 谓心中抽汞而化精，肾内升铅而变气，精气为物变化，而自结刀圭。 夫心中抽汞者，汞去则真水下降，是离卦去阴而成乾体。 乾，天也，轻清而无阴。 人能契之，则自然七情灰灭，六欲冰消。 谓肾内升铅者， 铅离则真火上行，是坎卦去阳而为坤象。 坤，地也，重浊而无阳。 人能契之，则自然三聚成圆，万缘心泯。 好道君子，请事斯语矣。 尝闻广成子曰：夫天枢之上，天元一气主之； 天枢之下，地元一气主之； 天枢之中，阴阳之源从之。 谓修真之士，形肖天地，头圆象天，清阳之本，斡旋七曜，应动一枢，辅弼紫微虚谷，元神拱之。 黄帝曰：效七政运虚之道，夺阳炼阴也。 且贪、巨者，应两耳也。 辅弼灵台，使诸尘不染，万缘不挂，得神识寂然而定。 谓禄、文者，应两目也。 若张之则神泄於外，闭之则神定於内。 夫廉、武者，通辅弼之径，贯玄牝之门，是天地根基，性命关钥。 依时互换，绵绵若存，得五神交感，而丹炉火炽矣。 谓破军者，镇守金关，密封地户，真风内扇，水气难攻。 令缄闭金胎，使不得漏失，赤龙精气，致三尸遁迹。 以心寒六贼，望风而胆碎，得火烧金鼎，水泛玉关，始一身元气，上下三田而贯矣。 谓周身八卦者，离为绛宫，是甲巳会合之乡，虎龙变生之地，乃万神之宅也。
chunks.translated_text:
In all who cultivate the true Dao, one must clarify the causes of refining metal and wood, thoroughly investigate the principles of host and guest in their preservation or loss, rely on the fire’s timing without error, and follow the measures for withdrawing and adding lead and mercury. Then, without waiting for days, the elixir will naturally form.

Master Pingshu notes: Nurturing the elixir without fire is like a mother holding a dead fetus—prolonged effort yields no result, only futile labor. How is this different in principle from metal and wood, which only reveal their natures when refined by fire?

**Water and Fire: Attainment and Non-Attainment**
The natures of water and fire mutually contain and gestate one another. Within water there is fire, and within fire there is water. What is meant by "within water there is fire"? Water belongs to the northern *Kan* trigram, embracing yang within yin. That water can reflect objects is the true fire. In the human body’s five viscera, water corresponds to the kidneys, which store essence—essence being fire.

What is meant by "within fire there is water"? Fire belongs to the southern *Li* trigram, embracing yin within yang. The blackness at the heart of fire is the true water. In the five viscera, fire corresponds to the heart, which governs blood—blood being water.

The *Book of Changes* states: "When water is above fire, it is *jiji* (attainment); when fire is above water, it is *weiji* (non-attainment)." Master Pingshu notes: "Within water, three fires gather; within fire, water refines and steams." All who cultivate the Dao rely on method and image to harmonize yin and yang, mastering the subtle transformations of the key and lock, causing water and fire to ascend and descend. By adding and withdrawing in accord with *jiji* and *weiji*, lead and mercury naturally congeal within the crucible, and the elixir forms—then golden light fills the chamber.

**Water and Fire Ascend and Descend Through Earth**
The *Book of Changes* states: "Water flows toward the moist; fire tends toward the dry." Without awareness, they respond to one another, revealing the principle of nature. Yet water is said to moisten and descend, fire to flame and ascend. How then, in *jiji*, does water remain above while fire stays below? Within *Kan* water there is fire because *Kan* receives *wu* (yang), which is pure and becomes essence, transforming into clear yang qi that ascends to become true water. Within *Li* fire there is water because *Li* receives *ji* (yin), which is turbid and becomes blood, transforming into heavy turbid qi that descends to become true fire.

Water and fire are the true qi of Heaven’s origin, born from the spleen. The spirit of the spleen governs creation alone, residing at the center, revolving the four directions, ascending and descending with each breath. When the qi of Heaven’s origin moves, one breath contains five—subtly aligning with the five phases.

The *Book of Changes* states: "Heaven’s number is five; Earth’s number is six"—the central number of yin and yang. This central number refers to earth. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Earth flourishes in the four seasons, weaving from beginning to end. Green, red, white, and black each occupy a direction, while the central palace receives the work of *wu* and *ji*." Master Pingshu also says: "The four images and five phases all rely on earth." Without the central qi of *wu* and *ji* circulating between *Kan* and *Li*, the divine elixir will never be produced.

**The Qi of Kan and Li Transform and Return to the Origin**
Within the heart, mercury is concealed; within the kidneys, lead is hidden. How are these two substances to be employed? Through the inverted technique of the five phases, true fire transforms into divine water, lead and mercury become wandering souls, and breath rises with the wind—naturally accomplishing the work of creation.

When the qi of Heaven’s origin stirs in the kidneys, *Kan*’s *wu* is yang, and one exhalation moves five. When the qi of Earth’s origin stirs in the heart, *Li*’s *ji* is yin, and one inhalation moves five. The movement of yin and yang qi combines to make ten. The *Book of Changes* states: "Heaven is nine; Earth is ten"—*wu* and *ji* naturally unite.

Drawing mercury from the heart transforms it into essence; ascending lead from the kidneys transforms it into qi. Essence and qi become things and change, naturally coagulating into the *daogui*. When mercury is drawn from the heart, true water descends, and the *Li* trigram sheds its yin to become the *Qian* body. *Qian* is Heaven—light and clear, without yin. Those who align with this naturally extinguish the seven emotions and melt the six desires like ice.

When lead ascends from the kidneys, true fire rises, and the *Kan* trigram sheds its yang to become the *Kun* image. *Kun* is Earth—heavy and turbid, without yang. Those who align with this naturally gather the three into a circle, and the myriad conditions of the heart dissolve.

Devotees of the Dao, take heed of these words.

I have heard Guangchengzi say: "Above the celestial pivot, the qi of Heaven’s origin governs; below the celestial pivot, the qi of Earth’s origin governs; at the celestial pivot, the source of yin and yang follows." Those who cultivate the Dao model their forms on Heaven and Earth. The head is round like Heaven, the root of clear yang, revolving the seven luminaries, responding to the movement of the pivot, assisting the Purple Tenuity and the Valley of Emptiness, with the primordial spirit encircling it.

The Yellow Emperor said: "Imitate the way the seven luminaries revolve in emptiness—seizing yang to refine yin." *Tan* and *Ju* correspond to the two ears. They assist the numinous terrace, preventing the dust of the world from staining it, the myriad conditions from clinging to it, so that the spirit’s awareness becomes still and settled.

*Lu* and *Wen* correspond to the two eyes. If they are opened, the spirit scatters outward; if closed, the spirit settles within. *Lian* and *Wu* connect the path of the assisting ministers, piercing the Gate of the Mysterious Female—the root of Heaven and Earth, the key to nature and life. Exchanging them in due time, continuously as if present, the five spirits interact, and the elixir furnace’s fire blazes.

*Pojun* guards the Metal Pass, sealing the Earth’s gate, fanning the true wind within, so that water qi cannot assail. It secures the golden womb, preventing leakage, and the essence of the red dragon causes the Three Corpses to flee. With the heart cold and the six bandits trembling in fear, fire burns the golden crucible, water overflows the Jade Pass, and the original qi of the entire body flows through the three fields above and below.

The eight trigrams of the body: *Li* is the Crimson Palace, the meeting place of *jia* and *si*, the land where tiger and dragon transform and arise—the dwelling of the ten thousand spirits.

chunks.original_text: 夫坎隐两玄，乃攒簇五行，合和四象，精光共聚，戊癸归根，号太一之宫矣。 肺丁藏魄也，不惊悸以能安。 肝庚隐魂也，无喜怒而常静。 壬甲主大肠而传道，巽辛附胆性以中和。 坤土为曲江而返复阴阳，艮山注水源而生清真浩气。 此七政八卦之用，乃阴阳根蒂，造化金丹，妙不可量。 《阴符经》云：七政成功，黄芽内长，八卦周围，神光黯淡。 《易·系辞》云：圣人立象以尽意，设卦以尽情。 会真集卷之一竟 会真集卷之二 超然子王吉昌撰 行香子　木金间隔 木性慈仁，体顺融金。 混难分、返复浮沉。 还元祖性，造化幽深。 得木抽金，金去木，罢相侵。 精变游魂，湛入禅心。 杳冥时、踪迹难寻。 无中显有，透古通今。 自魄安魂，魂胜魄，鬼神钦。 又 震内藏庚，金乙成姻。 假冲和、雷电交陈。 龙吟虎啸，幽谷澄神。 向杳冥中，风云裹，傲全身。 烟雨蒙蒙，芝草芽新。 正东君、经纬长春。 岷山火衮，一而藏真。 已泯抽添，无间隔，返归纯。 又
chunks.translated_text:
The *Kan* trigram conceals the Two Mysteries, gathering the Five Phases, harmonizing the Four Images; essence and light converge, *wu* and *gui* return to their root—this is called the Palace of the Great One.

The *ding* of the lungs stores the *po*; undisturbed by fright, it remains at peace. The *geng* of the liver conceals the *hun*; free from joy and anger, it abides in stillness. *Ren* and *jia* govern the large intestine, transmitting the Dao; *xun* and *xin* adhere to the gallbladder’s nature, maintaining central harmony. The *kun* earth forms the Winding River, reversing and returning yin and yang; the *gen* mountain pours forth the water source, generating pure and vast primordial *qi*. These are the functions of the Seven Governors and Eight Trigrams—the root and stem of yin and yang, the alchemy of the golden elixir, whose wonders cannot be measured.

As the *Yinfu Jing* states: "When the Seven Governors achieve success, the yellow sprout grows within; when the Eight Trigrams encircle, the divine light dims and fades." The *Xici* of the *Yijing* says: "The sage establishes images to fully express meaning, sets forth trigrams to fully convey the essence."

*Huizhen Ji*, Scroll One concludes
*Huizhen Ji*, Scroll Two
By Chaoranzi Wang Jichang

**Xingxiangzi**

Wood and metal stand apart,
Wood’s nature kind and yielding,
Its form in harmony with metal.
Hard to distinguish—reversing, floating, sinking.
Returning to the ancestral nature,
The workings of creation profound.
Wood draws forth metal,
Metal departs wood—
Their mutual encroachment ceases.

Refined essence transforms the wandering *hun*,
Deeply entering the meditative heart.
In the boundless dark,
Traces are hard to find.
From nothing, something appears,
Penetrating ancient and modern.
The *po* is settled, the *hun* secure,
The *hun* prevails over the *po*—
Even ghosts and spirits revere it.

**Again**

Within *Zhen* lies *geng*,
Metal and *yi* form a union.
Borrowing harmony,
Thunder and lightning intertwine.
Dragon’s chant, tiger’s roar—
The secluded valley clarifies the spirit.
Amidst the boundless dark,
Wind and clouds enfold,
The whole self stands aloof.

Misty rain, hazy,
The germ of the magic mushroom fresh.
The Eastern Lord
Weaves the warp and weft of eternal spring.
The fire of Min Mountain swirls,
Hiding the true within.
No more extraction or addition,
No separation—
Returning to purity.

The eight trigrams of the body: *Li* is the Crimson Palace, the meeting place of *jia* and *si*, the land where tiger and dragon transform and arise—the dwelling of the ten thousand spirits.

chunks.original_text: 震乙情柔，酷爱庚金。 角商和、律应清音。 木人鼓掌，石女调琴。 显巧施仁，勤行义，道情深。 二物相融，交互浮沉。 火煎烹、体变而金。 开蒙既济，阳炼胜阴。 得复根元，分魂魄，识真心。 行香子　木去金 木隐金形，金色浮存。 木森森、有像称尊。 全凭火力，逗引游魂。 自客先还，独存主，各归根。 去往碁分，性命云屯。 乐天真、默默昏昏。 养成阳体，霞步高奔。 得傲玄玄，跻寿域，出乾坤。 行香子　金去木 金体坚刚，木性柔和。 辩宾主、火力功多。 刚为主掌，柔像销磨。 显各还元，归本性，息风波。 透入神炉，霞罩嵯峨。 放银铅、花绽婆娑。 辉光满室，神变无何。 镇玩蓬宫，游紫府，恣蹉跎。 南乡子　水火交互既济 坎内一阳停，本性澄清照物形。 真火炎炎功足显，叮咛。 既济氤氲缉宝瓶。 神用奋威灵，气证升沉聚戊丁#1。 日耀飞腾烹药鼎，兰馨。 造化功成入杳冥。 又
chunks.translated_text:
Within *Zhen*, *yi* is tender in nature,
Passionately loving *geng*-Metal.
Wood and Metal harmonize,
Their notes attuned to pure sound.
The wooden man claps his hands,
The stone maiden tunes her zither.
Manifesting skill through benevolence,
Diligently practicing righteousness—
The Dao’s sentiment runs deep.
Two elements fuse,
Mutually rising and sinking.
Fire refines and simmers,
The body transforms as Metal melts.
Once ignorance is dispelled through completion,
Yang’s refinement prevails over Yin.
Regaining the root and origin,
Distinguishing *hun* and *po*,
Recognizing the true heart.

**Xingxiangzi: Wood Yields to Metal**

Wood withdraws, Metal’s form concealed,
Yet Metal’s hue lingers on.
Wood stands dense,
Assuming a revered semblance.
Wholly reliant on fire’s power,
It entices the wandering *hun*.
The guest first returns,
The host alone remains—
Each reverts to its root.
Departure and return divide like stones on a board,
Nature and life gather like clouds.
Delighting in celestial truth,
Silent and dim,
Nurturing the Yang body,
Treading misty steps in lofty ascent.
Attaining the boundless mystery,
Ascending the realm of longevity,
Emerging beyond Heaven and Earth.

**Xingxiangzi: Metal Yields to Wood**

Metal’s body is firm and unyielding,
Wood’s nature gentle and harmonious.
Discerning host and guest,
Fire’s power achieves much.
The firm assumes mastery,
The yielding dissolves like mist.
Each reveals its return to origin,
Reverting to true nature,
Quelling the winds and waves.
Penetrating the divine crucible,
Enveloped in rosy clouds,
Silver lead is released—
Flowers bloom in graceful dance.
Radiance fills the chamber,
The spirit transforms without bounds.
Abiding in the Peng Palace,
Roaming the Purple Courts,
Freely wandering at will.

**Nanxiangzi: Water and Fire Intermingle in Completion**

Within *Kan*, a single Yang abides,
Its true nature clear, illuminating forms.
True fire blazes fiercely, its power fully revealed—
Attend closely!
Completion’s misty vapors seal the precious vessel.
The spirit exerts its mighty efficacy,
Qi’s ascent and descent testify to *wu* and *ding*.
Sunlight soars, refining the cauldron of medicine,
Its fragrance like orchids.
The work of creation complete,
It enters the boundless dark.

**Again**

chunks.original_text: 火裹六阴培，炽艳心藏点黑煤。 功表清泠真水象，神胚。 中气抽添自往来。 赫赫振金雷，烟雨弥漫映斗魁。 造化自家天地合，心灰。 拍塞乾坤道体恢。 南乡子　水火升降因土 戊己媾阴阳，斡运专权摄四傍。 驱驾天元随呼吸，非常。 来往绵绵造化昌。 气聚结玄霜，壶鼎冰凝透体香。 神变灵通归物外，清凉。 无碍真空置道场。 又 离苑绿波飞，坎殿澄清奋火威。 变化降升凝真象，功归。 土德恢弘斡妙机。 梨枣体娇肥，玉女殷慧献紫微。 香衬彩霞光日月，巍巍。 无像圆明法界辉。 南乡子　坎离气变还元 癸府隐银铅，朱汞神宫袅瑞烟。 变化游魂成风动，枢旋。 运入黄庭造化权。 离去水为乾，坤体无阳厚德全。 二气经营仙药就，功圆。 出世名标闻九天。 又
chunks.translated_text:
**Within Fire, Six Yins Nurture**

Within fire, the six Yins are cultivated,
Fiercely ablaze, the heart’s core bears a speck of black coal.
The work manifests as the pure, cool image of true water—
A spirit-embryo.
The central qi withdraws and replenishes, moving of its own accord.
Resplendent, it shakes the golden thunder,
Mists and rains suffuse, reflecting the Dipper’s majesty.
Creation’s work unites heaven and earth as one,
The heart reduced to ashes.
Clapping, the cosmos is sealed—
The Dao-body restored in grandeur.

**Nanxiangzi: Water and Fire Ascend and Descend Through Earth**

*Wu* and *ji* wed yin and yang,
Wielding sole authority to govern the four directions.
They drive and harness the primordial, following breath’s rhythm—
Beyond the ordinary.
In ceaseless ebb and flow, creation flourishes.
Qi gathers, congealing into mysterious frost,
The crucible’s ice solidifies, its fragrance permeating the body.
The spirit transforms, transcending all things—
Cool and serene.
Unobstructed true emptiness establishes the Dao’s realm.

**Again**

From the *Li* garden, green waves take flight,
In the *Kan* palace, clarity stirs fire’s might.
Transformations descend and ascend, coalescing into true form—
The work is complete.
Earth’s virtue expands, mastering the subtle mechanism.
The pear and jujube’s form, plump and tender,
The Jade Maiden, wise and radiant, offers to the Purple Tenuity.
Fragrance adorns rosy clouds, outshining sun and moon—
Majestic.
Formless, perfectly luminous, the dharmadhātu shines.

**Nanxiangzi: Kan and Li’s Qi Transforms and Returns to the Origin**

In the *Gui* palace, silver lead lies concealed,
Cinnabar mercury in the spirit-palace wafts auspicious smoke.
Transforming, the wandering soul becomes a stirring wind—
The pivot turns.
It enters the Yellow Court, wielding creation’s power.
*Li* departs, water becomes *Qian*,
The *Kun* body, devoid of Yang, embodies full virtue.
The two qi refine the immortal elixir—
The work is perfected.
Emerging into the world, its name resounds through the nine heavens.

chunks.original_text: 水府火笼藏，烟雾朦胧琐桂光。 气动随风成造化，中央。 聚变刀圭药味香。 不见坎中阳，虚室无阴本体彰。 育出朝元真浩气，琼浆。 攒簇丹垆结玉霜。 醉桃源　贪狼巨门 杓枢贪巨秉天真。 玄皇附耳亲。 扶持五蕴已通神。 都收万劫尘。 寂然定，体清新。 温存一性纯。 冥冥物外傲长春。 逍遥月作邻。 醉桃源　禄存文曲 禄存文曲附神光。 驱驱逐色忙。 昧禅徒乱角和商。 如何作道场。 双帘掩，琐明堂。 仙童夺正阳。 神功机在性昭彰。 冥冥混八方。 醉桃源　武曲廉贞 武廉幽贯地天根。 绵绵息若存。 六天交战定朝昏。 丹炉火力温。 驱神窟，养生门。 玄功主掌尊。 牝关天闭炼阳魂。 云霁性命屯。 醉桃源　破军 破军雄镇北方阴。 牢封地户深。 真风高卷锁猿心。 氤氲气制禽。 三田贯，五神钦。 元胎体变金。 群魔离位九阳临。 功成耀古今。 醉桃源　左辅右弼玄牝 司分木火地天通。 玄关主掌雄。 鹿羊神辂逗真风。 都归保运功。 枢九窍，贯三宫。 熏蒸药鼎红。 万神辐辏性疏通。 无形廓太空。 又 暗藏两曜抚坤乾。 绵绵息斡旋。 扶持来往贯三田。 还元五气全。 河车运，玉炉煎。 炎炎结汞铅。 彩霞光衬晃禅天。 明明性月圆。 醉落魄　八卦配九宫 阴阳气结。 乾坤振、六爻交设。 四分九数明罗列。 两遁推移，周岁用相迭。 殷懃进取功无缺。 抽添加减应时节。 烹成二八丹威烈。 吸海吞山，方寸道明彻。 木兰花慢　坤卦老阴之象 剖坤柔立象，太阴体，换三阳。 因六变心虚，关开实腹，应候呈祥。 冲和易灵变态，运圣功、旋转斡天罡。 消息栽培道化，六宫毂辏中央。 融融品物含章。 归土德，密收藏。 性与命咸通，个中将养，气孕玄霜。 香浮彩霞烜赫，混浩然、纯粹散诸方。 造化冥冥极妙，超凡不离玄黄。 木兰花慢　乾卦老阳之象 判乾元刚象，德纯贞，利元亨。 运一气氤氲，施生品物，分布形成。 调和四时简易，正始终、机动应经营。 日月东西出没，总因元气流行。 参罗列曜循环，晃寥廓，体轻清。 尽变化无方，杳冥真造，内隐精诚。 酝就命基性烛，混太虚、模样貌峥嵘。 了了真空无碍，八弦挥斥难名。 风入松 乾坤两卦上天梯。 分柔健高低。 六关爻变推天道，斡璇玑、日月东西。 妙采精华成液，通神息，饮刀圭。 溶溶金水泛曹溪。 得九转功齐。 变成丹体香风袅，木童喜、寿域长跻。 显出元初气艳，廓胸襟，吐虹霓。 又 乾坤罗列道纲维。 斡斗转星移。 守迁飞伏随方变，应周天、衰旺相推。 保护坎离丹药，启玄牝，契希夷。 冥冥杳杳入无为。 会三姓相期。 应时烹炼循火数，结圆明、二八芳姿。 彻地通天圣变，表身外，显容仪。 又 乾坤爻变括天心。 枢简易浮沉。 斡旋升降成甘露，种黄芽、陆地根深。 潋滟滋荣金蕊，丹霞照，万神钦。 云收天静酒重斟。 韵聒耳呜琴。 醺醺酩酊乘风舞，恣神怡、鼓掌歌吟。 深入洞天静境，得真乐，写知音。 又 阴阳爻变坼乾坤。
chunks.translated_text:
**Water Palace enshrouds the flame in mist,**
Hazy vapors veil the cassia’s radiance.
Qi stirs with the wind, forging creation—
At the center,
The blade’s measure gathers, the elixir’s fragrance rises.

The Yang within *Kan* remains unseen,
The empty chamber, void of Yin, reveals its true nature.
It nurtures the primal *hao*-qi of dawn’s origin—
Jade nectar.
The crucible clusters, congealing crystalline frost.

---

**Drunk in Peach Blossom Spring: Greedy Wolf and Great Gate**
The Dipper’s handle, Greedy Wolf, Great Gate—endowed with celestial truth.
The Dark Sovereign whispers secrets in the ear.
Upholding the five aggregates, they penetrate the divine.
Gathering the dust of ten thousand kalpas—
Silent and still, the body renewed,
Warmth preserves the pure, undivided nature.
In the boundless beyond, they scorn the fleeting spring,
Carefree, with the moon as neighbor.

**Drunk in Peach Blossom Spring: Wealth Star and Literary Curve**
Wealth Star, Literary Curve—clinging to the spirit’s light,
Hastening, chasing after form in vain.
Foolish Chan disrupts the harmony of tones—
How can this be a Daoist sanctuary?
Double curtains drawn, the sacred hall sealed,
The immortal youth seizes the true Yang.
The divine work’s mechanism shines in the nature’s clarity—
In the profound, the eight directions merge.

**Drunk in Peach Blossom Spring: Military Star and Integrity**
Military Star, Integrity—threading earth and heaven’s root,
Ceaseless breath, as if abiding.
The six heavens wage war, fixing dawn and dusk,
The crucible’s fire gently warms.
Driving the spirit’s cavern, nurturing life’s gate,
The mysterious work holds sway in reverence.
The female pass, heaven’s seal, refines the Yang soul—
Clouds disperse, nature and life converge.

**Drunk in Peach Blossom Spring: Breaker of Armies**
Breaker of Armies, mighty guardian of the northern Yin,
Sealing the earth’s gate deep within.
The true wind billows high, restraining the monkey’s heart,
The misty qi subdues the bird.
Three fields aligned, the five spirits revere—
The primordial embryo’s body transmutes to gold.
Demons flee as the nine Yangs descend—
The work complete, its glory resounds through past and present.

**Drunk in Peach Blossom Spring: Left Assistant and Right Guardian of the Mysterious Female**
Governing wood and fire, earth and heaven’s communion,
The mysterious pass wields sovereign might.
Deer and ram, divine chariots, lure the true wind—
All converge in the work of preserving destiny.
The pivot of nine apertures, threading the three palaces,
Steams the elixir crucible crimson.
Myriad spirits gather, the nature’s channels unobstructed—
Formless, it expands into the vast void.

---

**Hidden, the twin luminaries cradle Qian and Kun,**
Ceaseless breath, the pivot turns.
Upholding the ebb and flow, threading the three fields,
Returning to the origin, the five qi complete.
The river chariot moves, the jade crucible refines,
Fiery flames bind mercury and lead.
Rosy clouds adorn the dazzling Chan heavens—
Luminous, the moon of nature rounds.

---

**Intoxicated and Lost: The Eight Trigrams Align with the Nine Palaces**
Yin and Yang’s qi conjoins,
Qian and Kun stir, the six lines interweave.
Four divides nine, the numbers arrayed in clarity.
The two cycles shift, a year’s course unfolds in succession.
Diligently advancing, the work knows no lack.
Withdrawing and adding, reducing and augmenting—timely.
The twin eights’ elixir, potent and fierce, is wrought.
Inhaling the sea, devouring mountains,
The Dao within the square inch shines resplendent.

---

**Magnolia Flower Slow: The Kun Trigram’s Image of Old Yin**
The yielding Kun establishes its form,
The Great Yin’s body, exchanging three Yangs.
Through six transformations, the heart empties,
The pass opens, the belly fills—timely omens appear.
In harmonious ease, the numinous shifts its guise,
Wielding sacred power, revolving the celestial pivot.
The Dao’s cultivation bears fruit,
Six palaces converge at the center.
Fused and radiant, the myriad things embody pattern,
Returning to earth’s virtue, closely concealed.
Nature and life commune,
Within, nurturing the qi—it gestates the mysterious frost.
Fragrance wafts, rosy clouds blaze,
Merging with the vast, the pure disperses in all directions.
Creation’s profound mystery—
Transcending the mundane, yet never apart from the primal yellow.

**Magnolia Flower Slow: The Qian Trigram’s Image of Old Yang**
The firm Qian manifests its primal form,
Virtue pure and steadfast, fundamentally flourishing.
A single qi, misty and diffuse,
Bestowing life upon the myriad things, apportioning their forms.
Harmonizing the four seasons with ease,
From beginning to end, the mechanism moves in accord with enterprise.
Sun and moon rise and set in the east and west,
All flows from the primordial qi’s circulation.
Arrayed like stars in their revolutions,
Vast and boundless, the body light and clear.
Endless transformations, no fixed abode,
The profound and obscure true creation,
Within, conceals sincerity.
Fermenting the foundation of life, the candle of nature,
Merging with the great void,
Its visage lofty and towering.
Lucid, the true emptiness knows no hindrance—
The eight extremities cannot name it.

---

**Wind Enters the Pines**
Qian and Kun, the two trigrams—ladder to heaven,
Dividing the supple and firm, high and low.
The six passes’ lines shift, revealing heaven’s Dao,
Turning the celestial pivot, sun and moon traverse east and west.
Mysteriously gathering the essence’s bloom into liquid,
Communing with the spirit, breathing—imbibing the blade’s measure.
Flowing gold and water overflow Cao Creek,
The nine revolutions’ work complete.
Transmuting into the elixir’s body, fragrant winds waft,
The Wood Lad rejoices, ascending the realm of longevity.
The primal qi’s splendor manifests,
Expanding the breast, exhaling rainbows.

---

Qian and Kun arrayed, the Dao’s warp and weft,
The Dipper turns, the stars drift.
Guarding the cyclical rise and fall, adapting to change,
Responding to the celestial round, decline and flourishing alternate.
Safeguarding the *Kan* and *Li* elixir,
Awakening the mysterious female, uniting with the profound and subtle.

Manifesting beyond the body, revealing countenance.

Melodies echo, the zither’s song rings in the ear.

Deep within the grotto-heaven’s quiet realm,
True bliss attained, inscribing the knowing friend.
